title: JavaVariables - Q0001
text: [Java Basics - Variables] What is a variable in Java?

options.text: A container for storing data values

explanation: A variable is a container that holds data values during program execution.

title: JavaVariables - Q0002
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which keyword is used to declare a variable in Java?
explanation: The 'var' keyword can be used for local variable type inference in Java 10 and later.

title: JavaVariables - Q0003
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a valid variable declaration?
explanation: Variable names cannot start with a digit or contain hyphens.

title: JavaVariables - Q0004
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is not a valid variable name?
explanation: Variable names cannot begin with a number.

title: JavaVariables - Q0005
text: [Java Basics - Variables] What is the default value of an int variable in Java?
explanation: The default value of an int variable is 0.

title: JavaVariables - Q0006
text: [Java Basics - Variables] What is the default value of a boolean variable?
explanation: The default value of a boolean variable is false.

title: JavaVariables - Q0007
text: [Java Basics - Variables] What is the default value of a reference variable?
explanation: Reference variables default to null.

title: JavaVariables - Q0008
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a valid way to declare multiple variables of the same type?
explanation: Multiple variables of the same type can be declared using commas.

title: JavaVariables - Q0009
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a valid variable initialization?
explanation: The correct syntax for initialization is 'type variable = value;'.

title: JavaVariables - Q0010
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a valid variable name in Java?
explanation: Variable names cannot be Java keywords, but 'Class' (capitalized) is valid.

title: JavaVariables - Q0011
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a primitive data type variable?
explanation: int is a primitive data type variable.

title: JavaVariables - Q0012
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a reference type variable?
explanation: String is a reference type variable.

title: JavaVariables - Q0013
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following statements declares a constant variable?
explanation: The 'final' keyword is used to declare constants in Java.

title: JavaVariables - Q0014
text: [Java Basics - Variables] What is the scope of a local variable?

options.text: Within the method or block where it is declared

explanation: Local variables are accessible only within the method or block where they are declared.

title: JavaVariables - Q0015
text: [Java Basics - Variables] What is the scope of an instance variable?
explanation: Instance variables are accessible throughout the class.

title: JavaVariables - Q0016
text: [Java Basics - Variables] What is the scope of a static variable?

options.text: Throughout the class and shared among all instances

explanation: Static variables are shared among all instances of a class.

title: JavaVariables - Q0017
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about static variables?
explanation: Static variables belong to the class, not to any specific object.

title: JavaVariables - Q0018
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about instance variables?

options.text: They are declared inside a class but outside any method
They are declared using the static keyword

explanation: Instance variables are declared inside a class but outside any method.

title: JavaVariables - Q0019
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about local variables?

options.text: They must be initialized before use
They are accessible outside the method

explanation: Local variables must be initialized before use.

title: JavaVariables - Q0020
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following can be used to access a static variable?
explanation: Static variables can be accessed using the class name or an object reference.

title: JavaVariables - Q0021
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about final variables?

options.text: They can be reassigned after initialization
They cannot be reassigned once initialized

explanation: Final variables cannot be reassigned once initialized.

title: JavaVariables - Q0022
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a valid declaration of a static variable?
explanation: The correct syntax is 'static int count;'.

title: JavaVariables - Q0023
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable naming conventions in Java?

options.text: Variable names can start with a number
Variable names can start with a letter or underscore
Variable names can contain special characters like @

explanation: Variable names can start with a letter, underscore, or dollar sign.

title: JavaVariables - Q0024
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is a valid variable name?
explanation: Variable names cannot contain spaces or hyphens and cannot start with a number.

title: JavaVariables - Q0025
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable initialization?

options.text: Static variables must be initialized manually

explanation: Instance variables are automatically initialized with default values.

title: JavaVariables - Q0026
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable shadowing?

options.text: A local variable can hide an instance variable with the same name
An instance variable can hide a local variable
Static variables can hide local variables
Shadowing is not allowed in Java

explanation: A local variable can shadow an instance variable with the same name.

title: JavaVariables - Q0027
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which keyword is used to define a variable that cannot change its value?
explanation: The 'final' keyword makes a variable constant.

title: JavaVariables - Q0028
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about static variables?

options.text: They are created when an object is created
They are created when the class is loaded
They are destroyed when the object is destroyed
They are local to a method

explanation: Static variables are created when the class is loaded into memory.

title: JavaVariables - Q0029
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about instance variables?

options.text: They are shared among all objects
Each object has its own copy

explanation: Each object has its own copy of instance variables.

title: JavaVariables - Q0030
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about local variables?

options.text: They are stored in the heap
They are stored in the stack
They are stored in the method area
They are stored in the constant pool

explanation: Local variables are stored in the stack memory.

title: JavaVariables - Q0031
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about instance variables?

options.text: They are stored in the heap
They are stored in the stack
They are stored in the method area
They are stored in the constant pool

explanation: Instance variables are stored in the heap memory.

title: JavaVariables - Q0032
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about static variables?

options.text: They are stored in the heap
They are stored in the method area
They are stored in the stack
They are stored in the constant pool

explanation: Static variables are stored in the method area.

title: JavaVariables - Q0033
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about final variables?

options.text: They can be initialized later in a constructor
They must be initialized at declaration

explanation: Final instance variables can be initialized in a constructor.

title: JavaVariables - Q0034
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable types?

options.text: Java supports both primitive and reference variables

explanation: Java supports both primitive and reference variables.

title: JavaVariables - Q0035
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable naming?

options.text: Variable names can start with a number

explanation: Variable names in Java are case-sensitive.

title: JavaVariables - Q0036
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable initialization?
explanation: Instance variables are automatically initialized with default values.

title: JavaVariables - Q0037
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable scope?
explanation: Instance variables have object-level scope.

title: JavaVariables - Q0038
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable lifetime?

options.text: Local variables exist until the method ends
Instance variables exist until the object is destroyed
Static variables exist until the class is unloaded

explanation: Each variable type has a different lifetime as described.

title: JavaVariables - Q0039
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable accessibility?

options.text: Protected variables are accessible only within the same class
Default variables are accessible only within the same method

explanation: Public variables are accessible from any class.

title: JavaVariables - Q0040
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable declaration?

options.text: Variables must be declared before use
Variables can be used without declaration
Variables can be declared after use

explanation: Variables must be declared before they are used in Java.

title: JavaVariables - Q0041
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable types?
explanation: Primitive variables store values directly, while reference variables store addresses.

title: JavaVariables - Q0042
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable reassignment?
explanation: Non-final variables can be reassigned new values.

title: JavaVariables - Q0043
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable initialization order?

options.text: Static variables are initialized before instance variables
Instance variables are initialized before static variables

explanation: Static variables are initialized when the class is loaded, before instance variables.

title: JavaVariables - Q0044
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable naming conventions?

options.text: Variable names should start with uppercase letters
Variable names should start with lowercase letters
Variable names should be all uppercase

explanation: By convention, variable names start with lowercase letters.

title: JavaVariables - Q0045
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable scope in loops?

options.text: Variables declared inside a loop are accessible outside
Variables declared inside a loop are accessible only within the loop
Variables declared inside a loop are global
Variables declared inside a loop are static

explanation: Variables declared inside a loop are accessible only within that loop.

title: JavaVariables - Q0046
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable lifetime in methods?

options.text: Local variables exist until the method ends
Local variables exist until the program ends
Local variables exist until the class is unloaded
Local variables exist until the object is destroyed

explanation: Local variables exist only during the method execution.

title: JavaVariables - Q0047
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable accessibility modifiers?

options.text: Private variables are accessible only within the same class
Public variables are accessible only within the same package
Default variables are accessible from any package

explanation: Private variables are accessible only within the same class.

title: JavaVariables - Q0048
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable declaration using var?

options.text: var can be used for instance variables
var can be used only for local variables
var can be used for static variables
var can be used for method parameters

explanation: The 'var' keyword can only be used for local variable type inference.

title: JavaVariables - Q0049
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following is true about variable initialization using literals?
explanation: All are valid examples of variable initialization using literals.

title: JavaVariables - Q0050
text: [Java Basics - Variables] Which of the following best describes a variable?

options.text: A named memory location used to store data

explanation: A variable is a named memory location used to store data.
